required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 09, 2023
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cemented vs. Cementless Unicompartmental Knee Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized Study Comparing Cemented and Cementless Fixed Bearing Unicondylar Medial Knee Replacement

brief_summary.textblock: The primary study objective is to evaluate a cementless partial knee system that has a modular 3-D printed porous metal tibial component and a cemented partial knee system. The hypothesis is that at minimum 2-year follow-up, fixed bearing medial partial knee replacements using cementless and cemented fixation will demonstrate no differences in clinical outcome.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, randomized, unblinded clinical trial of 100 patients will be enrolled by invitation of the principal investigator. Inclusion criteria include patients 18-85 years old, patients receiving a medial fixed bearing partial knee replacement and patients deemed suitable for both cemented and cementless fixation after review of the preoperative radiographs. Minimum two-year outcome will be analyzed, and long-term follow-up will continue to 5 years.

primary_outcome.description: Clinical score for knee status and function

intervention.description: Three dimensional printed porous metal, a biomaterial with morphological and mechanical properties that resemble those of native trabecular bone, is now being used for fixation of the tibial component in unicondylar knee arthroplasty. This can reliably achieve osseointegration into the tibia and could lead to a lower risk of aseptic loosening which is the leading cause of revision in partial knee replacements.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Inclusion criteria include patients 18-85 years old, patients receiving a medial fixed bearing partial knee replacement and patients deemed suitable for both cemented and cementless fixation after review of the preoperative radiographs.
Exclusion Criteria:
Non-English speakers, current smokers, and patients with grossly porotic bone will be excluded. Additional exclusion criteria include more advanced other compartment arthritis at the time of surgery necessitating a total knee arthroplasty (TKA), previous high tibial osteotomy with prior hardware, and patients who are randomized but are deemed unsuitable to receive the assigned implant by the surgeon due to bone quality or bone cuts.
